episodeTitle: Justice for the Winners! Sengoku's Strategy in Action!
description: The Marineford War reaches a fever pitch as Little Oars Jr. falls to the combined might of the Warlords. Koby and Helmeppo witness Akainu's brutal justice firsthand. Garp joins Ace on the execution platform, reminiscing about wanting the boys to become Marines. As the execution time is moved up, a battleship falls from the sky, revealing Luffy and the escaped Impel Down prisoners arriving at Marineford.

events.title: Hangan and Reforte Lead Allied Forces
events.description: Pirate captains Hangan and Reforte, allied with the Whitebeard Pirates, order their forces to charge into Marineford Bay. They stand alongside other allied captains including Arthur as they push forward to save Ace.
events.significance: Introduces two of the many allied pirate captains who joined Whitebeard's cause to rescue Ace, showing the breadth of Whitebeard's influence and alliances.

events.title: Doflamingo Controls Atmos with His Devil Fruit
events.description: Donquixote Doflamingo demonstrates his mysterious Devil Fruit ability by taking control of Atmos, the 13th Division Commander of the Whitebeard Pirates. Under Doflamingo's control, Atmos is forced to attack his own crew members with his sword, showing the horrifying nature of Doflamingo's powers.
events.significance: First clear demonstration of Doflamingo's ability to control people like puppets during the Marineford War. This showcases the psychological warfare element of the battle and establishes Doflamingo as a particularly dangerous Warlord.

quotes.text: I'm at the center of history!
quotes.speaker: Donquixote Doflamingo
quotes.context: Doflamingo reveling in his position at the war that will change the world

events.title: Tsuru's Woshu Woshu no Mi Debuts
events.description: Vice Admiral Tsuru demonstrates her Woshu Woshu no Mi Devil Fruit ability for the first time. She literally 'washes and hangs out to dry' attacking pirates as if they were laundry, neutralizing them with her unique powers. Sengoku contacts her via Den Den Mushi to put 'the strategy' into action.
events.significance: Reveals Tsuru's Devil Fruit ability and establishes her as a capable combatant despite her elderly appearance. Shows the Marines have diverse abilities among their high-ranking officers.

events.title: Little Oars Jr. Falls in Battle
events.description: After being attacked by multiple Warlords—hit by Kuma's Ursus Shock, having his leg severed by Doflamingo's strings, and finally being impaled through the midsection by Gecko Moria's Tsuno-Tokage (shadow spear)—Little Oars Jr. finally collapses. Despite his severe injuries, he desperately reaches toward Ace until his last moment, coming within inches before falling.
events.significance: Marks the defeat of one of the Whitebeard Pirates' most powerful allies and demonstrates the overwhelming power of the assembled Warlords. Little Oars Jr.'s determination to save Ace despite fatal wounds shows the deep bonds within Whitebeard's crew.

events.title: Whitebeard's Kabutowari Technique
events.description: Giant Vice Admiral Lonz launches a surprise attack on Whitebeard, but Whitebeard responds with a devastating new technique called Kabutowari (Helmet Splitter). He grabs Lonz's head and concentrates his Gura Gura no Mi vibrations around it, shattering the giant's helmet and defeating him in a single blow before throwing him aside.
events.significance: Demonstrates a new application of Whitebeard's earthquake powers focused on a single target rather than wide-area attacks. Shows that even in his weakened state, Whitebeard can easily defeat giant Vice Admirals.

events.title: Akainu Executes Deserting Marine
events.description: Koby and Helmeppo, fleeing the battlefield in terror, witness Admiral Akainu confronting a Marine soldier who wants to leave the battle to return to his family. Akainu declares that if the soldier cares for his family, he 'must not live with shame' and instantly executes him with his magma powers. This brutal act terrifies the already frightened Marines, including Koby and Helmeppo who watch from hiding.
events.significance: Demonstrates Akainu's extreme interpretation of 'Absolute Justice' and his willingness to kill his own subordinates for desertion. This is described as 'perhaps the first clear death scene in the present timeline' and establishes Akainu's ruthless character. The scene deeply impacts Koby's view of the Marines.

quotes.text: If you care for your family, you must not live with shame!
quotes.speaker: Akainu
quotes.context: Akainu justifying the execution of a deserting Marine before killing him

events.title: Garp's Emotional Flashback with Ace and Luffy
events.description: Garp joins Ace on top of the execution platform, overwhelmed with emotion as he remembers happier times when Ace and Luffy were children. He recalls how he wanted them both to grow up to become strong Marines rather than pirates. Both Garp and Ace burst into tears as they confront the tragic outcome of their choices, with Sengoku watching and comprehending Garp's profound pain.
events.significance: Reveals the deep emotional conflict Garp faces—torn between his duty as a Marine and his love for his grandsons. This moment humanizes both Garp and Ace, showing the personal tragedy underlying the war. It establishes the failed dreams Garp had for the boys.

events.title: Ace's Execution Time Moved Up
events.description: Sengoku announces that Ace's execution time has been changed and moved up, accelerating the timeline before the expected deadline. This is part of the Marines' strategy to end the war quickly and deny Whitebeard's forces more time to mount a rescue.
events.significance: Raises the stakes dramatically and puts pressure on all forces. This strategic decision by Sengoku forces Whitebeard's hand and sets up the climactic moments of the war. It shows the Marines are willing to deviate from their announced plans.

events.title: Luffy and Impel Down Escapees Arrive at Marineford
events.description: In a dramatic turn of events, a battleship falls from the sky into Marineford Bay. Emporio Ivankov had performed a Hell Wink hoping to slide the ship down a frozen wave, but instead knocked it forward, flipping it upside-down. By sheer luck, it landed in one of the few unfrozen spots of ocean. The impact split the boat in two, revealing Luffy, Buggy, Crocodile, Jinbe, Ivankov, Mr. 1, Mr. 3, and other escaped Impel Down prisoners.
events.significance: Marks Luffy's dramatic entrance into the war to save his brother Ace. This moment shifts the entire dynamic of the battle and shocks all present forces—Marines, Whitebeard Pirates, and Warlords alike. It represents the culmination of Luffy's journey through Impel Down.

events.title: Luffy and Ace Reunite at Marineford
events.description: As Luffy climbed onto the wrecked battleship, he and Ace spotted each other across the battlefield. Ace called out to Luffy, who happily responded that he was glad to see him again. Meanwhile, Sengoku became infuriated at Garp and his 'accursed family,' while Garp remained in shock that Luffy had made his way to Marineford despite all obstacles.
events.significance: The emotional reunion between the brothers at the heart of the war. This moment confirms to Ace that Luffy came all this way for him, and to the world that the two condemned criminals are brothers. Sengoku's fury at Garp shows the personal complications within the Marine leadership.

quotes.text: I'm at the center of history!
quotes.speaker: Donquixote Doflamingo
quotes.context: Doflamingo reveling in his position at the war

quotes.text: If you care for your family, you must not live with shame!
quotes.speaker: Akainu
quotes.context: Akainu justifying the execution of a deserting Marine

themes.description: The episode's title 'Justice for the Winners' encapsulates Doflamingo's philosophy that justice is defined by those in power. Akainu's execution of a deserting Marine demonstrates 'Absolute Justice' taken to its extreme, contrasting with Garp's personal conflict between duty and family.
themes.symbolism: The execution platform represents the Marine's absolute authority, while the falling battleship symbolizes chaos disrupting established order.

themes.description: Garp's emotional breakdown on the execution platform highlights the impossible choice between his Marine duty and his love for Ace and Luffy. The deserting Marine's desire to return to his family versus Akainu's demands for duty represents this conflict at multiple levels.
themes.symbolism: Garp's tears represent the human cost of war and rigid adherence to duty.

themes.description: Little Oars Jr.'s final moments show unwavering determination to save Ace despite fatal wounds. His sacrifice, like those of many others in this war, demonstrates the lengths people will go to for their bonds and beliefs.
themes.symbolism: Oars reaching toward Ace with his dying breath symbolizes the unbreakable bonds of Whitebeard's crew.

themes.description: The episode shows war's toll on all sides—from Little Oars Jr.'s death to Koby and Helmeppo's terror to the executed Marine. It reveals that war creates victims among both enemies and allies.
themes.symbolism: Koby and Helmeppo's fear and witness of execution represents the loss of innocence in war.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy's arrival at Marineford represents the culmination of his desperate journey through Impel Down. His determination to save Ace despite impossible odds showcases his unwavering loyalty to his brother.
keyActions: Falls from the sky on a battleship with Impel Down escapees
Spots and calls out to Ace across the battlefield
Shocks all three factions (Marines, Whitebeard Pirates, Warlords) with his arrival

characterSpotlights.development: Garp's emotional breakdown reveals the depth of his internal conflict. His flashback to wanting Ace and Luffy to become Marines shows his failed dreams and the personal tragedy he faces watching Ace's execution.
keyActions: Joins Ace on the execution platform
Recalls memories of young Ace and Luffy
Breaks down in tears alongside Ace
Reacts in shock to Luffy's arrival

characterSpotlights.development: Akainu's execution of a deserting Marine establishes him as a terrifying force who values duty and victory above all else, including the lives of his own subordinates. This moment defines his character's extreme interpretation of justice.
keyActions: Confronts a Marine soldier attempting to desert
Executes the deserter with magma powers
Terrifies other Marines including Koby and Helmeppo
quotes: If you care for your family, you must not live with shame!

characterSpotlights.development: Ace's emotional moment with Garp shows his own regrets about the path he chose. His reaction to seeing Luffy arrive demonstrates both joy at seeing his brother and horror that Luffy has put himself in such danger.
keyActions: Learns his execution time has been moved up

characterSpotlights.development: Little Oars Jr.'s death scene emphasizes his loyalty to Ace and the Whitebeard Pirates. His determination to reach Ace even while dying from multiple fatal wounds shows the strength of bonds in Whitebeard's crew.
keyActions: Continues advancing despite being impaled by Moria
Reaches toward Ace with his final strength
Collapses, creating destruction across the bay

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends several battle sequences, particularly the Warlords' attacks on Little Oars Jr., with additional action animation not present in the manga.
Garp's emotional flashback with young Ace and Luffy is expanded in the anime with additional scenes and more detailed animation of their childhood.

trivia.fact: Episode 465 covers Chapter 556 (pages 2-17) of the manga. The chapter is titled 'Justice Will Prevail!!' which aligns with the episode's theme about the subjective nature of justice.
The opening song 'One day' by The Rootless was used for episodes 459-492, covering the majority of the Marineford Arc. This opening is known for its emotional tone matching the war's intensity.

The Burning Lizard Studios reviewer noted they went from 'bawling my eyes out, literally crying harder than I ever have for any sad scene' during Garp's flashback to 'busting my gut laughing by the end of the episode' with Luffy's arrival, highlighting the episode's emotional range.

The scene of the battleship falling from the sky mirrors the composition and character order shown in the opening theme 'Kaze o Sagashite' (used in episodes 426-458), creating a visual callback for viewers.

This episode features one of the first explicit on-screen deaths in One Piece's present timeline with Akainu's execution of the deserting Marine, marking a tonal shift in the series toward showing the brutal reality of war.

Crocodile incorrectly blamed Ivankov for their fall from the sky in this episode, which was later proven wrong in Episode 466 when it was revealed Ivankov's Hell Wink actually saved them from certain death.

Episode 465 aired on September 5, 2010 in Japan, at a time when the manga was at Chapter 596 - meaning the anime was approximately 40 chapters behind the manga, relatively close compared to later years.
The eyecatcher for this episode features Brook and Luffy, foreshadowing Luffy's arrival at Marineford shown later in the episode.
